BC-CANCER-DECLINE-BOS 
REPORT SEES DROP IN DEATH RATE, INCIDENCE FROM CANCER 

   (For use by New York Times News Service clients)  
 By JUDY FOREMAN  
 c.1999 The Boston Globe  
 

   In a report that suggests that the United States has ``turned
the corner'' on cancer, the government says both the death rate and
incidence of new cancer cases declined significantly for all types
of the disease between 1990 and 1996.

   The latest ``cancer report card'' says the rate of new cancers
has gone down an average of nearly 1 percent a year over the study
period and that the mortality rate has dropped a little more than
0.5 percent.

   The results are published in the current Journal of the National
Cancer Institute, which also included an editorial lauding the
report.

   But the study results also came Tuesday with a warning. Unless
an alarming increase in teenage smoking can be reversed, the
researchers said, declining lung cancer rates _ a big part of the
improving cancer picture _ will probably start rising again.

   The report was compiled by the American Cancer Society, a
private organization, and three government groups: the National
Cancer Institute, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention,
and the National Center for Health Statistics.

   ``It is astonishing that almost half of all high school children
in America currently use some form of tobacco,'' Dr. Howard Koh, a
medical oncologist and the public health commissioner for
Massachusetts, said in the editorial.

   In this century, Koh said in a telephone interview, the tobacco
industry was allowed to make a product that drove ``a cancer that
used to be rare into our leading cancer killer in men and women.''

   There has been a phenomenal 73 percent increase in smoking among
teenagers between 1988 and 1996, said Barbara Rimer, director of
the division of cancer control and population sciences at the
National Cancer Institute. ``It's outrageous . . . it's
horrifying.''

   ``We need to do something about these high school students;
otherwise we will have another lung-cancer epidemic,'' said Phyllis
Wingo, lead author of the report and director of surveillance
research at the cancer society.

   Nevertheless, the report's accompanying editorial said America
``has turned the corner'' on cancer.

   Another report in the same issue of the journal reported that
seven European studies show that smoking cigars, cigarillos, and
pipe tobacco is almost as closely linked to lung cancer as smoking
cigarettes.

   Because lung cancer accounts for 14 percent of new cancer cases
and 28 percent of cancer deaths, the biggest impact on cancer can
be made by fighting tobacco use, the main report said. About 90
percent of lung cancer is caused by smoking cigarettes, cigars, and
pipes and by second-hand exposure to smoke.

   The gains made against cancer vary by type of cancer, gender,
age, race, and ethnicity. Overall, the greatest decline in
incidence has been among men, who have higher rates of cancer than
women.

   But some cancers _ non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and melanoma _ are not
showing improvements. Both the incidence and the death rate from
non-Hodgkin's lymphoma have continued to rise, although the rate of
increase appears to have slowed recently, Wingo said in a telephone
interview.

   With melanoma, incidence continued to rise almost three percent
a year, while the death rate held steady. Like lung cancer, noted
Koh, melanoma is a highly preventable cancer. About 70 percent of
cases are linked to excess sun exposure.

   The new figures show striking disparaties in lung cancer between
men and women. The incidence of lung cancer went down an average of
2.6 percent per year for men, but went up 0.1 percent for women,
noted Rimer. And the death rate for lung cancer went down 1.6
percent for men but went up 1.4 percent for women.

   That's because men started smoking earlier in the century and
started quitting sooner as well. Women are about ``a decade behind
in stopping,'' Rimer of the NCI said, although researchers are
starting to see the numbers improve for younger women (aged 40 to
59).

   Overall, the prevalence of cigarette smoking has declined among
adults in the last 25 years, but this trend has stalled in the past
four to five, the researchers said.

   For colorectal cancer, the news is more gender-balanced.
Incidence and death rates declined for both men and women. It's too
soon to tell whether this is due to increased screening.

   Prostate cancer also declined in incidence and mortality,
although this was not statistically significant, noted Rimer. For
years, the incidence had been rising, but much of that rise was
probably due to increased screening with a test called PSA. The
peak incidence was in 1992, the report shows.

   Breast cancer incidence remains unchanged, but death rates have
declined at about 2 percent a year since 1990. Part of that, cancer
epidemiologists believe, is due to increased use of screening
mammograms, which about two-thirds of women over 65 now get. Part
of the improvement in death rates is also probably due to more
widespread use of treatments such as chemotherapy.

   But the breast cancer mortality rate continues to show a racial
disparity. Black women are somewhat less likely than white women to
get the disease, but they are more likely to die from it.

   With leukemia, overall mortality is down 0.3 percent, and
incidence is down 1.1 percent, with no large gender differences.
``We honestly don't know why there has been a decrease in
mortality,'' said Rimer.

   ``These findings underscore the remarkable progress we've made
against cancer, but it also reminds us that our battle is far from
over,'' said Health and Human Services Secretary Donna E. Shalala
in a statement released Tuesday.

   For children younger than 15 years old, the incidence of cancer
declined 0.4 percent a year between 1990 and 1996 and mortality
decline 2.7 percent.

   The greatest decrease in overall incidence of cancer has
occurred since 1992, the year in which incidence rates peaked.

   The report also analyzed cancer data for whites, blacks,
Asians/Pacific Islanders, American Indians/Alaskan Natives and
Hispanics. There were large differences in incidence by race and
ethnicity, with the highest incidence rates for blacks for all the
major types of cancer except breast cancer.

     
(For more information on this study, see the Web site
www-seer.ims.nci.nih.gov)
